[MS. Bodl. Ashmole 59, leaves 62â64.] Nowe here nexst folowyng ys made a balade by Lydegate, sente by a poursyvant to Ã¾e Shirreves of London, acompanyed with Ã¾eire breÃ¾erne vpon Mayes daye at Busshopes wod, at an honurable dyner, eche of hem bringginge his dysshe. 1 Mighty Flourra, goddes of fresshe floures, Whiche cloÃ¾ed hast Ã¾e soyle in lousty grene, Made buddes springe with hir swote showres By influence of Ã¾e sonne so sheene; To do plesaunce of entent ful clene Vn-to Ã¾estates wheoche Ã¾at nowe sitte here, HaÃ¾e Veere dovne sent hir owen doughter dere, 2 Making Ã¾e vertue Ã¾at dured in Ã¾e roote, Called of clerkes Ã¾e vertue vegytable, For to trascende, moste holsome and moste swoote, In-to Ã¾e crope, Ã¾is saysoun so greable. Ãe bawmy lykour is so comendable Ãat it reioyÃ¾e with Ã¾e fresshe moysture Man, beeste, and foole, and every creature 3 Whiche haÃ¾e repressed, swaged, and bore dovne Ãe grevous constreinte of Ã¾e frostes hoore; And caused foolis, ffor ioye of Ã¾is saysoune, To cheese Ã¾eire makes Ã¾ane by natures loore, With al gladnesse Ã¾eire courage to restore, Sitting on bowes fresshly nowe to synge Veere for to salue at hir home comynge; 4 Ful pleinly meninge in Ã¾eire ermonye Wynter is goone, whiche did hem gret payne, And with Ã¾eire swoote sugre melodye, Thanking Nature Ã¾eire goddesse souereyne Ãat Ã¾ey nowe have no mater to compleyne, Hem for to proygne every morwenyng With lousty gladnesse at Phebus vprysinge. 5 And to declare Ã¾e hye magnifysence Howe Vere inbringeÃ¾e al felicytee, Affter wynters mighty vyolence Avoydinge stormys of al adversytee; For sheo haÃ¾e brought al prosperitee To alle Ã¾estates of Ã¾is regyoun At hir comynge to-fore youre hye renoun: 6 To Ã¾e mighty prynces Ã¾e palme of Ã¾eire victorie; And til knighthode nowe sheo doÃ¾e presente Noblesse in armes, lawde, honnour, & glorie; Pees to Ã¾e people in al hir best entente, With grace and mercy fully to consente Ãat provydence of hye discressioun Avoyde descorde and al devysyoun. 7 Wynter shal passe of hevynesse and trouble, F[l]owres shal springe of perfite charite, In hertes Ã¾ere shal be no meninge double, Buddes shal [blosme] of trouÃ¾e and vnytee, Pleinly for to exyle duplicytee, Lordes to regne in Ã¾eire noble puissance, Ãe people obeye with feythful obeyssaunce. 8 Of alle estates Ã¾ere shal beo oone ymage, And princes first shal ocupye Ã¾e hede, And prudent iuges, to correcte outrages, Shal trespassours const[r]eynen vnder drede, Ãat innosentes in Ã¾eire lowlyhede As truwe comvnes may beo Ã¾eire socour, Truwly contune in Ã¾eire faithful labour. 9 And by Ã¾e grace of Oure Lorde Ihesu Ãat Holly Chirche may have parseueraunce, Beo faythfull founde in al [vertu], Mayre, provost, shirreff, eche in his substaunce; And aldremen, whiche haue Ã¾e governaunce Over Ã¾e people by vertue may avayle, Ãat noone oppression beo done to Ã¾e pourayle. 10 Ãus as Ã¾e people, of prudent pollycye, Pryncis of Ã¾e right shal governe, Ãe Chirche preye, Ã¾e iuges iustefye, And knighthode manly and prudently discerne, Til light of trouÃ¾e so clerely Ã¾e lanterne: Ãat rightwysnesse thorughe Ã¾is regyoune Represse Ã¾e derknesse of al extorcyoune. 11 Ãeos be Ã¾e tyÃ¾inges, wheoche Ã¾at Weer haÃ¾e brought, Troubles exylinge of wynters rude derknesse; Wherfore reioye yowe in hert, wille, and thought, Somer shal folowe to yowe off al gladnesse; And siÃ¾en sheo is mynistre of lustynesse, Let hir beo welcome to yowe at hir comyng, Sith sheo to yowe haÃ¾e brought so glad tyÃ¾inge. 12 Ãe noble princesse of moste magnifisence, Qweene of al ioye, of gladde suffisaunce, May is nowe comen to Youre Hye Excellence, Presenting yowe prosperous plesaunce, Of al welfare moste foulsome haboundance, As sheo Ã¾at haÃ¾e vnder hir demayne Of floures fresshe moste holsome and soueraine.

Lenvoye to alle Ã¾estates present. 13 Ãis Princesse haÃ¾e, by favour of nature, Repared ageine Ã¾at wynter haÃ¾e so fade, And foolis loustely recvvre Ãeire lusty notes and Ã¾eire enemye glade, And vnder braunches vnder plesant shade Reioyssing Ã¾aire with many swote odoures, And Zepherus with many fresshe [shoures]. 14 Topyted fayre, with motleys whyte and rede, Alle hilles, pleynes, and lusty bankes grene, And made hir bawme to fleete in every mede, And fury Tytane shewe oute heos tresses sheene, And vppon busshes and hawthornes kene, Ãe nightingale with plesant ermonye Colde wynter stormes nowe sheo doÃ¾e defye. 15 On Parnoso Ã¾e lusty muses nyene, Citherra with hir sone nowe dwellis, Ãis sayson singe and Ã¾eire notes tuwyne Of poetrye besyde Ã¾e cristal wellis; Calyope Ã¾e dytes of hem tellis, And Orpheus with heos stringes sharpe SyngeÃ¾e a roundell with his temperd herpe. 16 Wher-fore to alle estates here present, Ãis plesant tyme moste of lustynesse, May is nowe comen to fore yow of entent To bringe yowe alle to ioye and fresshnesse, Prosparitee, welfare, and al gladnesse, And al Ã¾at may Youre Hyenesse qweeme and pleese, In any parte or doone youre hertes eese.
